content.description: <math alttext="The figure presents a 2 row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “x,” and the heading for row 2 is “f of x.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. x is 1. f of x is negative 0.2. Column 2. x is 3. f of x is negative 0.1. Column 3. x is 4. f of x is 0.5. Column 4. x is 7. f of x is 0.6. Column 5. x is 10. f of x is 0.8." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0.0em" columnwidth="3em 0.05em 3em 3em 3em 3em" equalrows="true" frame="solid" framespacing="0.0em 0.5ex" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="1ex" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>x</mi></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mn>1</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>7</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mspace depth="1.0ex" height="2.5ex" width="0.0em"></mspace></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.2</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.1</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mn>0.5</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.6</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>0.8</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: The continuous function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is known to be increasing for all <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Selected values of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. Let <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the left Riemann sum approximation for <math alttext="the integral from, 1 to 10, of, f of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></math> using the four subintervals indicated by the table. Which of the following statements is true?

choices.label: <math alttext="L, equals, 1.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and is an underestimate for <math alttext="the integral from, 1 to 10, of, f of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="L, equals, 1.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and is an overestimate for <math alttext="the integral from, 1 to 10, of, f of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="L, equals, 2.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and is an underestimate for <math alttext="the integral from, 1 to 10, of, f of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="L, equals, 2.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and is an overestimate for <math alttext="the integral from, 1 to 10, of, f of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="L, equals, 2.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and is an underestimate for <math alttext="the integral from, 1 to 10, of, f of x, d x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msubsup><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Explain how an approximated value relates to the actual value.
